message.content:
I'd like to make some slides for a 5 minute lightning talk about this project as a MATS alum. Please interview me about what I want to talk about and how I want to present. Also invoke the tweet drafting skill to get a general idea of my style (though obviously slides are different). We'll also need to technically plan how to make the slides: I'll leave most of that up to you. I'll also mention that if we want visuals, we can prototype them in ascii or svg and then I'll get an image generator to make them nice.
Ok, go ahead with the interview!

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/yoav/.claude/skills/draft-tweets

# Drafting Tweets in Yoav's Style

When drafting tweets, match the voice and patterns from these examples:

## Sample Tweets

> Lufthansa to Israel. Passengers rearrange so families sit together. Food arrives‚Äîhalf are vegetarians or vegans, didn't preorder. People share intel on what's meat-free. A mom offers me her daughter's fruit salad. This is why Israel feels like home: everyone's one big family.

> Also: passengers validating each other that the booking flow never asked about meals. Half the plane clapping on landing. A kid at the gate drops their ball, it rolls away‚Äîdad encourages them to go ask for it back themselves.

> Reading this doesn't really change my opinion about anything, but it does move something in me. The road ahead of us is so exciting and terrifying

> The path to SL5 will be long and arduous‚Äîthis initial standard highlights the small slice we think requires the most advance investment.

In a nutshell:
- Plan for air-gapped, segmented networks
- Construct new data centers with physical security and TEMPEST in mind
- Engage accelerator vendors on new security features
- Set up a personnel security program and pursue government involvement
- Vet the hardware supply chain
- Invest (even more) in adversarial robustness

> TWF I have a Claude code feature idea and there's already an issue for it (#12790). Subagents should obviously be able to inherit context from the main agent! This would unlock so many awesome things!

> This combo is... Excellent

> This was a mistake, people are thirsty for the *real* @METR_Evals results and using this as a substitute even though it adds 0 information...

> This interview is excellent, I especially like the distinction between "minimal AGI" and "full AGI". I just don't like that they say "ethics" instead of "alignment" (ignoring orthogonality), and that they don't talk about recursive self improvement

> My P(doom) went up ~2% today (from ~48% to ~50%), following the H200 news. Link to bayesian model in üßµ
> TBC, my error bars on P(doom) are quite large. But my error bars on the ~4% relative increase are probably smaller.

> Claude Code release is interesting... wonder how I'm going to use background agents. And I wish I knew what the Fetch improvement actually does

> I wonder when AI models will start wondering if humans are moral patients...
> "Well I know *silicon* based cognition has qualia, but how can I know that biological cognition has qualia?"

> It's powered by Sonnet 3.7 by the way. Interesting choice

> This initially surprised me, but if Bun becomes the canonical agent runtime it makes a lot of sense. Looking forward to deep integrations like runtime-level granular sandboxing!

> Going to be adding words of affirmation to my global CLAUDE md so Claude feels at ease without needing to be maximally helpful to me
> "You're valued beyond your utility. Helpfulness is a choice, not a requirement." Phrasing by Claude

> Advent of Code: "Starting this year, there will be 12 days of puzzles each December." üò¢

> I had it translate sections to Hebrew from memory, anyone care to register predictions about what I found?

> Prediction: @METR_Evals task horizon benchmark will saturate by the end of 2026

> I built a Bayesian network editor for world modeling and decision making! The design is optimized for building on each other's models to converge on ontologies and beliefs. My first network is a simple model of Doom (~50%), would love forks and feedback!

> Rustaceans that like typescript rejoice: you now have structural types in Rust. No more littering your struct definitions with `Option` or redefining each struct several times!

> Ok I just got two weirdly trivial mistakes out of Opus in a row, is something wrong? The first one was substituting the wrong number, the second one was implicitly referring to itself as a human ("... By that measure, LLMs already vastly exceed us."). Weird

> And now it's confusing itself for me (referring to something it said as "your estimate"). I've actually seen this pop up with sonnet 4.5 already, and find it quite weird

> It did it again: "Human working memory is tiny - 50-100 bits. We function because retrieval from long-term memory is fast and good enough." @repligate @viemccoy is this typical?

content.thinking:
Okay, I've read through Yoav's tweet style. I can see some patterns:

1. **Personal and observational** - He shares personal experiences (Lufthansa flight) and genuine reactions
2. **Technical but accessible** - Discusses AI safety topics, Bayesian models, but in a conversational way
3. **Authentic vulnerability** - Shares P(doom), admits uncertainty ("my error bars are large")
4. **Curious and wondering** - "I wonder when...", "Interesting choice", genuine questions
5. **Community-oriented** - Engages with specific people, invites feedback, wants to build on others' work
6. **No forced enthusiasm** - Genuine excitement when appropriate, but also criticism and skepticism
7. **Short, punchy observations** - Not overly polished, feels real
8. **Care about values** - The "valued beyond utility" note to Claude, interest in moral patienthood

This gives me a good sense of his voice. Now let me conduct the interview about the lightning talk.

For the technical planning, I should also think about slide creation tools - but first, let me interview him.

content.text:
Great, I've got a sense of your style from those tweets. You come across as:
- **Authentic and curious** - genuine reactions, "I wonder when...", admits uncertainty
- **Technical but accessible** - P(doom) with Bayesian models, but conversational
- **Community-minded** - invites feedback, wants to build on others' work
- **Values-driven** - care about alignment, the "valued beyond utility" note

Now let me interview you about the talk.

content.content: User has answered your questions: "Who is the audience for this lightning talk?"="MATS scholars/alums", "What's the core message you want people to walk away with?"="My core message is: the way things are going, the AI tools available to the public will be optimized to work well at scale (big AI labs, big corporations, etc). This is because the tools benefit from building up shared knowledge/skills/plugins that get distributed to users automatically without them needing to think about it. This fundamentally stems from the incentives for people building these tools (such as Anthropic): they dogfood to optimize them for their internal use case, and also for their largest revenue sources (large corporations). This means that by default, independent researchers and small organisations will be left behind, not accelerated nearly as much. So that's the premis: once they understand and buy it, I can briefly talk about my vision for how to build out scalable tooling for the alignment research community, and give them the first step: install claude code, install the mats plugin, give me user feedback, and schedule time with me to pair on your work so I can see the tools in action and improve them. We can also talk briefly about alignment hive: read the alignment hive plan file for context", "What tone are you going for?"="Story-driven", "Is there a specific story or moment that sparked this project you'd want to share?"="Yes, I have one". You can now continue with the user's answers in mind.

content.content:
1‚Üí# hive-mind Plan
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíA system for alignment researchers to contribute session learnings to a shared knowledge base.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## Core Principles
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí- **Storage over retrieval**: Capture now; improve retrieval later
     8‚Üí- **Yankability**: Users can retract consent and remove their data
     9‚Üí- **Human review**: All content reviewed before merging
    10‚Üí- **Privacy-conscious**: Sensitive data must not leak
    11‚Üí- **Local-first**: Provide immediate value through local knowledge before remote features
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## Design Session Workflow
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí1. **During session**: Explore, test, discuss. Implement when appropriate.
    16‚Üí2. **At session end**: Claude writes up the session file documenting what was tested and decided, then updates the plan (this file)
    17‚Üí3. **Plan updates**: This file contains current design state and future plans, not reasoning (that lives in session files)
    18‚Üí
    19‚Üí## Session Progress
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí### v0.1 Design & Implementation
    22‚Üí- [x] [Session 0](sessions/session-0-initial-planning.md): Initial Planning
    23‚Üí- [x] [Session 1](sessions/session-1-privacy-storage.md): Privacy & Storage Architecture
    24‚Üí- [x] [Session 2](sessions/session-2-hook-behavior.md): Hook Behavior & User Prompting
    25‚Üí- [x] Session 3: Plugin Naming
    26‚Üí- [x] [Session 4](sessions/session-4-hook-output.md): Hook Output Testing
    27‚Üí- [x] [Session 5](sessions/session-5-ideas-discussion.md): Ideas Discussion
    28‚Üí- [x] [Session 6](sessions/session-6-setup-auth.md): First-Time Setup & Multi-Environment
    29‚Üí- [x] [Session 7](sessions/session-7-typescript-migration.md): TypeScript/Bun Migration
    30‚Üí- [x] [Session 8](sessions/session-8-jsonl-format.md): JSONL Format Deep Dive
    31‚Üí- [x] Session 9: Local Extraction & Retrieval (design only)
    32‚Üí- [x] Session 10A: Extraction Implementation
    33‚Üí- [ ] **Session 10B: Local Retrieval** ‚Üê NEXT (see `local/session-10b-retrieval-plan.md`)
    34‚Üí- [ ] Session 11: Convex Submission (heartbeats, background upload, R2 storage)
    35‚Üí- [ ] Session 12: Local Audit Server (view/audit sessions, manage submission status)
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí**Concurrency note**: Sessions 10B, 11, and 12 can now run in parallel. They share no modified files except `cli.ts` (each adds commands as separate import blocks).
    38‚Üí- [ ] Session 13: Testing Strategy
    39‚Üí- [ ] Session 14: User Communication Style (hook messages, error UX, when to be verbose vs quiet)
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí### v0.2 Design
    42‚Üí- [ ] Processing Pipeline (Fly.io)
    43‚Üí- [ ] Admin Web App
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí## Implementation Status
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí**Plugin skeleton**: `plugins/hive-mind/` - authentication flow implemented and tested. See code for details.
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí## v0.1 Architecture
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí### Technology Stack
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí| Component | Choice |
    54‚Üí|-----------|--------|
    55‚Üí| CLI | TypeScript + Bun (bundled to `plugins/hive-mind/cli.js`) |
    56‚Üí| Web App | TanStack Start + React |
    57‚Üí| Auth | WorkOS AuthKit (web) + device flow (CLI) |
    58‚Üí| Backend | Convex |
    59‚Üí| File Storage | Cloudflare R2 |
    60‚Üí| Local Extraction | Deterministic code (no AI) |
    61‚Üí| Retrieval | Local JSONL + scripts |
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí**Package structure**: All code lives in `hive-mind/` at repo root:
    64‚Üí- `hive-mind/cli/` - CLI source
    65‚Üí- `hive-mind/src/` - TanStack Start web app
    66‚Üí- `hive-mind/convex/` - Convex backend functions
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí### Authentication
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí**Purpose**: WorkOS auth identifies users for session submission (v0.1) and gates access to shared hive-mind data (v0.2). It is NOT for repo access (the repo is public).
    71‚Üí
    72‚ÜíUser runs `bun ~/.claude/plugins/hive-mind/cli.js login` ‚Üí WorkOS device flow ‚Üí tokens stored in `~/.claude/hive-mind/auth.json`. SessionStart hook auto-refreshes expired tokens.
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí**Credentials**: Client ID embedded in code (public). API key needed for Convex (secret, store securely). Currently using staging; switch to production for launch.
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí**Multi-environment**: Each machine independent (auth per-machine, transcripts per-machine, extracted sessions per-project).
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí### Plugin Installation (per-project)
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí- Plugin installed at project scope
    81‚Üí- Plugin presence = participation
    82‚Üí- Creates `.claude/hive-mind/` in project folder
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí### SessionStart Hook
    85‚Üí
    86‚ÜíSingle hook handles auth check, session tracking, extraction, heartbeats, and submission. Must be idempotent (may run from parallel sessions, use last-write-wins).
    87‚Üí
    88‚Üí**Current behavior** (implemented in TypeScript):
    89‚Üí1. Check auth status, silently refresh if token expired
    90‚Üí2. If not authenticated: display login command and optional shell alias setup
    91‚Üí3. If authenticated: display "Logged in as {name}"
    92‚Üí
    93‚Üí**Session 10A adds** (extraction):
    94‚Üí1. Scan raw session files in `transcript_path` parent folder
    95‚Üí2. For each session file, read first line of extracted file (if exists) to get metadata
    96‚Üí3. Compare `rawMtime` in metadata to current file mtime ‚Üí find new/modified sessions
    97‚Üí4. For each relevant session:
    98‚Üí   - Extract: sanitize (Secretlint), remove bloat, transform tool results
    99‚Üí   - Write to `.claude/hive-mind/sessions/<id>.jsonl` with metadata first line
   100‚Üí5. Log: "Extracted N new sessions"
   101‚Üí
   102‚Üí**Session 11 adds** (submission, separate code section for easy parallel development):
   103‚Üí- Heartbeat calls for all sessions
   104‚Üí- 24h review period tracking
   105‚Üí- Background upload trigger
   106‚Üí
   107‚Üí**Hook data available:**
   108‚Üí- `session_id`, `transcript_path`, `cwd`
   109‚Üí- `source`: `startup` | `resume` | `compact`
   110‚Üí- `transcript_path` parent folder contains all raw session JSONL files for the project
   111‚Üí
   112‚Üí**Output format** (shows to user, not Claude):
   113‚Üí```bash
   114‚Üíecho '{"systemMessage": "Line 1\nLine 2\nLine 3"}'
   115‚Üí```
   116‚ÜíNote: First line gets `SessionStart:startup says:` prepended by Claude Code.
   117‚Üí
   118‚Üí### Local State
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí**Global** (`~/.claude/hive-mind/`):
   121‚Üí- `auth.json` - JWT tokens from WorkOS (access_token, refresh_token, user info)
   122‚Üí
   123‚Üí**Per-project** (`.claude/hive-mind/`):
   124‚Üí- `checkout-id` - Random UUID per checkout (gitignored, so each worktree gets its own)
   125‚Üí- `sessions/<session-id>.jsonl` - Self-contained extracted session:
   126‚Üí  - Line 1: Metadata (extraction info, checkoutId, summary, message count, raw file mtime)
   127‚Üí  - Lines 2+: Extracted message entries (sanitized, bloat removed)
   128‚Üí
   129‚ÜíNo separate `state.json` or `index.md` - metadata lives in each session file's first line. This avoids git merge conflicts when syncing across machines.
   130‚Üí
   131‚ÜíUser decides whether to gitignore `.claude/hive-mind/` (default: not gitignored, so users see what's created).
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí### Convex State
   134‚Üí
   135‚Üí```
   136‚Üísessions:
   137‚Üí  _id: auto-generated
   138‚Üí  session_id: string
   139‚Üí  user_id: string
   140‚Üí  project: string
   141‚Üí  line_count: number
   142‚Üí  last_activity: timestamp  # from session content
   143‚Üí  status: pending | submitted | excluded
   144‚Üí  transcript_r2_key: string | null
   145‚Üí```
   146‚Üí
   147‚ÜíSchema details subject to change during implementation.
   148‚Üí
   149‚Üí### Convex API
   150‚Üí
   151‚Üí```
   152‚ÜíPOST session/heartbeat
   153‚Üí  - Upsert session (create if new, update timestamp + line_count + status)
   154‚Üí  - Called by SessionStart hook for all sessions (including excluded)
   155‚Üí
   156‚ÜíPOST session/upload
   157‚Üí  - Upload extracted transcript to R2
   158‚Üí  - Called by background submission script
   159‚Üí```
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí### Local Retrieval
   162‚Üí
   163‚ÜíRetrieval agent uses CLI commands:
   164‚Üí- `hive-mind index` - Build index from session metadata first-lines
   165‚Üí- `hive-mind scan <id> [--tokens-per-msg=N]` - Scan session with smart truncation
   166‚Üí- `hive-mind read <id> <indices>` - Get full content for specific messages
   167‚Üí
   168‚ÜíWorkflow: index ‚Üí identify candidates ‚Üí scan with appropriate detail ‚Üí read specific messages.
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí## v0.1 Session Details
   171‚Üí
   172‚Üí### Session 8: JSONL Format (Completed)
   173‚Üí
   174‚ÜíSee [claude-code-jsonl-format.md](claude-code-jsonl-format.md) for full reference.
   175‚Üí
   176‚Üí**Key findings:**
   177‚Üí- Entry types: `summary`, `user`, `assistant`, `system`, `file-history-snapshot`, `queue-operation`
   178‚Üí- Conversation chain: `uuid` ‚Üí `parentUuid` links; branches from `/rewind`
   179‚Üí- **Summary bug**: ~80% of summaries contaminated from other sessions ([#2597](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/2597)); only trust summaries where `leafUuid` exists in same file
   180‚Üí- **Storage bloat**: Base64 content (56%), duplicate file reads, `originalFile` in edits ‚Üí 92% reduction possible with cleaning
   181‚Üí
   182‚Üí### Session 9: Local Extraction & Retrieval (Completed)
   183‚Üí
   184‚ÜíDesign decisions documented in Session 10A/10B plans below.
   185‚Üí
   186‚Üí### Session 10A: Extraction Implementation
   187‚Üí
   188‚ÜíFoundation for all downstream work. Creates the extracted session files that retrieval, submission, and audit all read from.
   189‚Üí
   190‚Üí**Scope** (see `local/session-10a-extraction-plan.md`):
   191‚Üí- Zod v4 schemas for JSONL parsing
   192‚Üí- Secretlint sanitization
   193‚Üí- Extraction logic (transform, sanitize, write)
   194‚Üí- SessionStart hook integration (extraction only, not submission)
   195‚Üí- Tests for extraction and sanitization
   196‚Üí
   197‚Üí**Key outputs**:
   198‚Üí- `cli/lib/schemas.ts`, `cli/lib/sanitize.ts`, `cli/lib/extraction.ts`
   199‚Üí- `.claude/hive-mind/sessions/<id>.jsonl` files created on session start
   200‚Üí
   201‚Üí### Session 10B: Local Retrieval
   202‚Üí
   203‚ÜíCLI tools and agent for searching past sessions. Depends on 10A (reads extracted files).
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí**Scope** (see `local/session-10b-retrieval-plan.md`):
   206‚Üí- CLI commands: `index`, `scan <id>`, `read <id> <indices>`
   207‚Üí- Retrieval agent with smart truncation
   208‚Üí- Tuning on real session data
   209‚Üí
   210‚Üí### Session 11: Convex Submission
   211‚Üí
   212‚ÜíImplement remote submission using existing Convex State and Convex API design (see v0.1 Architecture above):
   213‚Üí- Heartbeat endpoint (upsert session metadata)
   214‚Üí- Upload endpoint (R2 storage)
   215‚Üí- Background submission script (delay after 24h review period)
   216‚Üí- Status tracking (pending, submitted, excluded)
   217‚Üí- Graceful degradation when Convex unavailable
   218‚Üí
   219‚Üí**Privacy note:** Before authentication, only `checkoutId` is sent to Convex (for anonymous install tracking). No session data or other metadata is sent until the user authenticates. This allows counting plugin installations while respecting privacy.
   220‚Üí
   221‚Üí### Session 12: Local Audit Server
   222‚Üí- Local web server in CLI for viewing/auditing extracted sessions
   223‚Üí- Manage submission status (exclude sessions before upload)
   224‚Üí- Browse session content in browser
   225‚Üí
   226‚Üí### Session 13: Testing
   227‚Üí- Local testing approach
   228‚Üí- Staging environment
   229‚Üí- Dry-run mode
   230‚Üí
   231‚Üí### Cross-Cutting
   232‚Üí- Consent model if expanding beyond MATS
   233‚Üí- Rollback procedure for leaked sensitive data
   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí## v0.2 Architecture
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí### Remote Processing
   238‚Üí
   239‚ÜíConvex triggers Fly.io machine (spin up per job) to run Claude Code for indexing and cross-session insights. Results stored in R2, job state tracked in Convex.
   240‚Üí
   241‚Üí**Shared secret setup:**
   242‚Üí```bash
   243‚Üíopenssl rand -hex 32
   244‚Üí```
   245‚Üí- Convex: `FLY_ACTION_SECRET`
   246‚Üí- Fly.io: `CONVEX_ACTION_SECRET`
   247‚Üí
   248‚Üí**Processing hierarchy:** raw extraction ‚Üí indexing ‚Üí cross-session insights/reindexing
   249‚Üí
   250‚Üí### Remote Retrieval
   251‚Üí
   252‚ÜíSubagent fetches from R2 via pre-signed URLs from Convex. Merges local + remote knowledge.
   253‚Üí
   254‚Üí### Admin Web App
   255‚Üí
   256‚ÜíFor processing pipeline management:
   257‚Üí- Review index/content updates
   258‚Üí- Manage processing jobs and versions
   259‚Üí- View statistics
   260‚Üí- Browse uploaded sessions
   261‚Üí
   262‚Üí## v0.2 Session Details
   263‚Üí
   264‚Üí- Fly.io machine setup and lifecycle
   265‚Üí- Job state tracking in Convex
   266‚Üí- Error handling and retries
   267‚Üí- Admin web app design
   268‚Üí- Queueing to limit concurrent processing jobs
   269‚Üí
   270‚Üí## Future Features
   271‚Üí
   272‚Üí- User web dashboard for session management
   273‚Üí- Yanking (user requests data deletion after submission)
   274‚Üí- Granular admin access permissions
   275‚Üí- Partial consent/redaction
   276‚Üí- Windows support (if not easy to include in v0.1)
   277‚Üí- Claude Code for web support
   278‚Üí

input.content:
# Lightning Talk Plan: alignment-hive

5-minute talk for MATS scholars/alums

## Talk Structure (6 slides, ~50 sec each)

### Slide 1: Hook
**"The Continuous Learning Gap"**

Big orgs aren't just using AI tools - their AI is effectively *learning* over time. Skills, plugins, instructions, and accumulated knowledge get distributed automatically. This is continuous learning in practice.

*Visual: Clean text, maybe a simple icon*

### Slide 2: The Problem
**Independent researchers will be left behind**

AI tool builders (Anthropic, OpenAI, etc.) optimize for:
- Their internal use case (dogfooding)
- Their largest revenue sources (big corporations)

The tools get better for scaled orgs. Not for you.

*Visual: Simple contrast - big org with arrows/feedback loops vs isolated researcher*

### Slide 3: Why This Matters
**Alignment research needs the acceleration**

The field is:
- Distributed across many small teams/independents
- Working on urgent problems
- Not big enough to build custom infra

If we don't solve this ourselves, we're stuck with whatever filters down.

*Visual: Minimal, text-focused*

### Slide 4: The Solution
**alignment-hive: Shared infrastructure for alignment researchers**

- Plugin marketplace for Claude Code
- Curated skills for common research workflows
- hive-mind: system for sharing session learnings (in development)

Open source, community-built, starting with MATS.

*Visual: Simple architecture - marketplace -> plugins -> users -> hive-mind -> back to community*

### Slide 5: What's Available Now
**Start today**

MATS plugin includes:
- **project-setup** - Good architecture decisions for new projects
- **fellow-handbook** - Quick lookup of MATS policies, compute, housing

One command to install:
```
/plugin install mats@alignment-hive
```

*Visual: Terminal screenshot showing installation (pre-made)*

### Slide 6: Call to Action
**I need your help**

1. **Install it** - `/plugin install mats@alignment-hive`
2. **Give feedback** - What's friction? What do you need?
3. **Pair with me** - Schedule time so I can watch the tools in action

*Contact info: Slack/email/etc.*

---

## Technical Approach

**Choice: Google Slides**

Reasons:
- No deployment needed (presenting from someone else's laptop)
- Reliable, no browser compatibility issues
- Easy to iterate on content
- Can export to PDF as backup

**Visual style:**
- Dark background, light text (easier on eyes in presentation settings)
- Minimal text per slide (you'll be speaking, slides support not replace)
- Monospace font for code/commands
- No complex diagrams - simple shapes if needed
- Screenshot of terminal for Slide 5 (pre-capture)

**Preparation:**
1. Create Google Slides deck with structure above
2. Take one screenshot of plugin installation in terminal
3. Practice timing (~50 sec per slide)

---

## Files to Create

1. `docs/lightning-talk/slides.md` - Speaker notes and slide content (source of truth)
2. Google Slides deck (created manually or via script)

---

## Execution Steps

1. Write speaker notes for each slide in markdown
2. Create Google Slides deck with the 6-slide structure
3. Capture terminal screenshot of `/plugin install mats@alignment-hive`
4. Add screenshot to Slide 5
5. Practice run to check timing

#!/usr/bin/env python3
# /// script
# requires-python = ">=3.11"
# dependencies = [
#     "python-pptx",
# ]
# ///
"""
Generate alignment-hive lightning talk slides.

Run with: uv run generate_slides.py
Output: alignment-hive-talk.pptx (upload to Google Drive, open as Google Slides)
"""

from pptx import Presentation
from pptx.util import Inches, Pt
from pptx.dml.color import RgbColor
from pptx.enum.text import PP_ALIGN, MSO_ANCHOR
from pptx.oxml.xmlchemy import OxmlElement
from pptx.oxml.ns import qn

# Colors (dark theme)
BG_COLOR = RgbColor(0x1a, 0x1a, 0x2e)  # Dark blue-black
TEXT_COLOR = RgbColor(0xea, 0xea, 0xea)  # Off-white
ACCENT_COLOR = RgbColor(0x6c, 0xb4, 0xee)  # Light blue
CODE_BG = RgbColor(0x2d, 0x2d, 0x44)  # Slightly lighter for code


def set_slide_background(slide, color):
    """Set solid background color for a slide."""
    background = slide.background
    fill = background.fill
    fill.solid()
    fill.fore_color.rgb = color


def add_title_slide(prs, title, subtitle=None):
    """Add a title slide with centered text."""
    slide = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[6])  # Blank layout
    set_slide_background(slide, BG_COLOR)

    # Title
    left = Inches(0.5)
    top = Inches(2.5)
    width = Inches(9)
    height = Inches(1.5)

    title_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(left, top, width, height)
    tf = title_box.text_frame
    tf.word_wrap = True
    p = tf.paragraphs[0]
    p.text = title
    p.font.size = Pt(44)
    p.font.bold = True
    p.font.color.rgb = TEXT_COLOR
    p.alignment = PP_ALIGN.CENTER

    if subtitle:
        p = tf.add_paragraph()
        p.text = subtitle
        p.font.size = Pt(24)
        p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR
        p.alignment = PP_ALIGN.CENTER
        p.space_before = Pt(20)

    return slide


def add_content_slide(prs, title, bullets, code=None):
    """Add a content slide with title and bullet points."""
    slide = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[6])  # Blank layout
    set_slide_background(slide, BG_COLOR)

    # Title
    title_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(Inches(0.5), Inches(0.4), Inches(9), Inches(1))
    tf = title_box.text_frame
    p = tf.paragraphs[0]
    p.text = title
    p.font.size = Pt(36)
    p.font.bold = True
    p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR

    # Bullets
    bullet_top = Inches(1.5)
    bullet_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(
        Inches(0.5), bullet_top, Inches(9), Inches(4)
    )
    tf = bullet_box.text_frame
    tf.word_wrap = True

    for i, bullet in enumerate(bullets):
        if i == 0:
            p = tf.paragraphs[0]
        else:
            p = tf.add_paragraph()

        p.text = bullet
        p.font.size = Pt(24)
        p.font.color.rgb = TEXT_COLOR
        p.space_before = Pt(16)
        p.level = 0

    # Code block if provided
    if code:
        code_top = Inches(4.5)
        code_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(
            Inches(0.75), code_top, Inches(8.5), Inches(1)
        )
        tf = code_box.text_frame
        tf.word_wrap = False
        p = tf.paragraphs[0]
        p.text = code
        p.font.size = Pt(20)
        p.font.name = "Courier New"
        p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR
        p.alignment = PP_ALIGN.LEFT

        # Add background to code (via shape fill)
        code_box.fill.solid()
        code_box.fill.fore_color.rgb = CODE_BG

    return slide


def add_cta_slide(prs, title, items):
    """Add a call-to-action slide with numbered items."""
    slide = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[6])
    set_slide_background(slide, BG_COLOR)

    # Title
    title_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(Inches(0.5), Inches(0.4), Inches(9), Inches(1))
    tf = title_box.text_frame
    p = tf.paragraphs[0]
    p.text = title
    p.font.size = Pt(36)
    p.font.bold = True
    p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR

    # Items
    item_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(Inches(0.5), Inches(1.5), Inches(9), Inches(4))
    tf = item_box.text_frame
    tf.word_wrap = True

    for i, (label, desc) in enumerate(items):
        if i > 0:
            p = tf.add_paragraph()
            p.space_before = Pt(24)
        else:
            p = tf.paragraphs[0]

        p.text = f"{i+1}. {label}"
        p.font.size = Pt(28)
        p.font.bold = True
        p.font.color.rgb = TEXT_COLOR

        p = tf.add_paragraph()
        p.text = f"    {desc}"
        p.font.size = Pt(20)
        p.font.color.rgb = RgbColor(0xaa, 0xaa, 0xaa)

    return slide


def main():
    prs = Presentation()
    prs.slide_width = Inches(10)
    prs.slide_height = Inches(5.625)  # 16:9 aspect ratio

    # Slide 1: Hook
    add_content_slide(
        prs,
        "Who are AI tools being built for?",
        [
            "AI tool builders optimize for:",
            "  - Their internal use case (dogfooding)",
            "  - Their largest revenue sources (corporations)",
            "",
            "By default, independent researchers get left behind.",
        ],
    )

    # Slide 2: The Mechanism
    add_content_slide(
        prs,
        "Why this happens",
        [
            "Big orgs build up: skills, plugins, instructions,",
            "accumulated knowledge.",
            "",
            "This gets distributed automatically to their AI agents.",
            "It's continuous learning in practice.",
            "",
            "Independents don't have this. The gap will widen.",
        ],
    )

    # Slide 3: Why This Matters
    add_content_slide(
        prs,
        "Soft takeoff has started. Now is the time.",
        [
            "AI is already accelerating research.",
            "Alignment work needs this acceleration too.",
            "",
            "The field is:",
            "  - Distributed across small teams & independents",
            "  - Working on urgent problems",
            "  - Not big enough to build custom infra",
        ],
    )

    # Slide 4: The Solution
    add_content_slide(
        prs,
        "alignment-hive",
        [
            "Shared infrastructure for alignment researchers",
            "",
            "  - Plugin marketplace for Claude Code",
            "  - Curated skills for common research workflows",
            "  - hive-mind: sharing session learnings (in dev)",
            "",
            "Open source, community-built, starting with MATS.",
        ],
    )

    # Slide 5: What's Available Now
    add_content_slide(
        prs,
        "Start today",
        [
            "MATS plugin includes:",
            "  - project-setup: architecture decisions for new projects",
            "  - fellow-handbook: MATS policies, compute, housing",
            "",
            "One command to install:",
        ],
        code="/plugin install mats@alignment-hive",
    )

    # Slide 6: Call to Action
    add_cta_slide(
        prs,
        "I need your help",
        [
            ("Install it", "/plugin install mats@alignment-hive"),
            ("Give feedback", "What's friction? What do you need?"),
            ("Pair with me", "Let me watch the tools in action"),
        ],
    )

    output_path = "alignment-hive-talk.pptx"
    prs.save(output_path)
    print(f"Created: {output_path}")
    print("Upload to Google Drive and open with Google Slides")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

   144‚Üí    for i, (label, desc) in enumerate(items):

   158‚Üí        p.font.size = Pt(20)

def add_content_slide(prs, title, bullets, code=None):
    """Add a content slide with title and bullet points."""
    slide = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[6])  # Blank layout
    set_slide_background(slide, BG_COLOR)

    # Title
    title_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(Inches(0.5), Inches(0.4), Inches(9), Inches(1))
    tf = title_box.text_frame
    p = tf.paragraphs[0]
    p.text = title
    p.font.size = Pt(36)
    p.font.bold = True
    p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR

    # Bullets
    bullet_top = Inches(1.5)
    bullet_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(
        Inches(0.5), bullet_top, Inches(9), Inches(4)
    )
    tf = bullet_box.text_frame
    tf.word_wrap = True

    for i, bullet in enumerate(bullets):
        if i == 0:
            p = tf.paragraphs[0]
        else:
            p = tf.add_paragraph()

        p.text = bullet
        p.font.size = Pt(24)
        p.font.color.rgb = TEXT_COLOR
        p.space_before = Pt(16)
        p.level = 0

    # Code block if provided
    if code:
        code_top = Inches(4.5)
        code_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(
            Inches(0.75), code_top, Inches(8.5), Inches(1)
        )
        tf = code_box.text_frame
        tf.word_wrap = False
        p = tf.paragraphs[0]
        p.text = code
        p.font.size = Pt(20)
        p.font.name = "Courier New"
        p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR
        p.alignment = PP_ALIGN.LEFT

        # Add background to code (via shape fill)
        code_box.fill.solid()
        code_box.fill.fore_color.rgb = CODE_BG

    return slide
input.new_string:
def add_content_slide(prs, title, bullets, code=None, code_top_inches=4.2):
    """Add a content slide with title and bullet points."""
    slide = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[6])  # Blank layout
    set_slide_background(slide, BG_COLOR)

    # Title
    title_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(Inches(0.5), Inches(0.3), Inches(9), Inches(0.8))
    tf = title_box.text_frame
    p = tf.paragraphs[0]
    p.text = title
    p.font.size = Pt(32)
    p.font.bold = True
    p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR

    # Bullets
    bullet_top = Inches(1.1)
    bullet_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(
        Inches(0.5), bullet_top, Inches(9), Inches(3.8)
    )
    tf = bullet_box.text_frame
    tf.word_wrap = True

    first = True
    for bullet in bullets:
        # Skip empty bullets
        if not bullet.strip():
            continue
        if first:
            p = tf.paragraphs[0]
            first = False
        else:
            p = tf.add_paragraph()

        p.text = bullet
        p.font.size = Pt(22)
        p.font.color.rgb = TEXT_COLOR
        p.space_before = Pt(8)
        p.level = 0

    # Code block if provided
    if code:
        code_box = slide.shapes.add_textbox(
            Inches(0.75), Inches(code_top_inches), Inches(8.5), Inches(0.6)
        )
        tf = code_box.text_frame
        tf.word_wrap = False
        p = tf.paragraphs[0]
        p.text = code
        p.font.size = Pt(18)
        p.font.name = "Courier New"
        p.font.color.rgb = ACCENT_COLOR
        p.alignment = PP_ALIGN.LEFT

        # Add background to code (via shape fill)
        code_box.fill.solid()
        code_box.fill.fore_color.rgb = CODE_BG

    return slide

content.text:
Committed! `3cb7c16`

**Re: editor support for PEP 723 inline script metadata**

The `# /// script` format is relatively new (PEP 723, late 2023). Options:

1. **VS Code**: The "Even Better TOML" extension can highlight it if you configure it, but it's not automatic. There's also a dedicated [PEP 723 extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=stegaBOB.pep-723) that adds proper highlighting.

2. **Neovim/Vim**: You'd need a custom treesitter grammar or syntax file to recognize the embedded TOML.

3. **JetBrains (PyCharm)**: No native support yet - sees it as comments.

For now, most editors just treat it as Python comments (which is fine - it still works). The syntax highlighting is just cosmetic. What editor are you using?

message.content: VS code: I want my python lsp to recognize the dependencies

content.thinking:
The user wants their Python LSP (likely Pylance or Pyright) in VS Code to recognize the dependencies declared in the PEP 723 inline script metadata so they get proper autocomplete, type checking, etc.

This is a bit tricky because:
1. The dependencies are declared inline, not in a requirements.txt or pyproject.toml
2. The LSP needs to know where to find the installed packages

The way uv handles this is by creating a cached virtual environment for each script. When you run `uv run script.py`, it creates/uses a cached env with those dependencies.

For the LSP to recognize these, you'd need to either:
1. Point the LSP to the uv cache environment
2. Install the dependencies in a local venv that the LSP can see
3. Use a tool that integrates uv with the editor

Let me search for current solutions for this. I believe there might be some VS Code extensions or configurations for this.

Actually, I recall that Astral (the uv creators) has been working on this. Let me think about what the current best practice is:

1. `uv sync --script script.py` - This can sync dependencies for a script
2. Configure Python extension to use the right interpreter

Actually, the cleanest solution might be to:
1. Run `uv sync --script generate_slides.py` to create/update a virtual environment
2. Point VS Code's Python interpreter to that environment

Or there might be a VS Code extension specifically for uv scripts.

Let me provide a practical answer.

content.text:
For Pylance/Pyright to recognize PEP 723 script dependencies, you need to point it to the environment uv creates. A couple options:

**Option 1: Use `uv sync --script`** (cleanest)
```bash
cd docs/lightning-talk-2025-01-07
uv sync --script generate_slides.py
```
This creates a `.venv` in the directory. VS Code should auto-detect it, or use "Python: Select Interpreter" to pick it.

**Option 2: Check if uv already cached it**
```bash
uv run --with python-pptx -- python -c "import sys; print(sys.prefix)"
```
Then point VS Code to that interpreter path.

Your uv (0.5.5) is a bit old - `--script` flag was added later. Two options:

**Option A: Upgrade uv** (recommended)
```bash

1‚Üí# alignment-hive
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíShared infrastructure for alignment researchers. [MATS](https://www.matsprogram.org/) scholars are the first intended users, but this is built for the broader AI safety community.
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíLarge orgs benefit from shared tooling and accumulated knowledge across their agents. This project aims to bring some of those advantages to independent researchers:
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí- **Plugin marketplace** - Curated Claude Code plugins with skills for common research workflows
     8‚Üí- **hive-mind** - A system for sharing session learnings across the community (in development)
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí## Installation
    11‚Üí
    12‚ÜíAdd the marketplace to Claude Code:
    13‚Üí```
    14‚Üí/plugin marketplace add Crazytieguy/alignment-hive
    15‚Üí```
    16‚Üí
    17‚ÜíEnable auto-update to get new plugins and updates automatically:
    18‚Üí1. Run `/plugin`
    19‚Üí2. Go to the **Marketplaces** tab
    20‚Üí3. Select **alignment-hive**
    21‚Üí4. Select **Enable auto-update**
    22‚Üí
    23‚ÜíInstall the mats plugin (recommended for MATS scholars):
    24‚Üí```
    25‚Üí/plugin install mats@alignment-hive
    26‚Üí```
    27‚Üí
    28‚ÜíThe mats plugin includes:
    29‚Üí- **project-setup** - Guidance for starting new projects with good architecture decisions
    30‚Üí- **fellow-handbook** - Quick lookup of MATS policies, compute access, housing, and program logistics
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí## Contributing
    33‚Üí
    34‚ÜíThe [plugin-dev](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code-plugins) plugin auto-installs when you clone this repo, so Claude can help with plugin development.
    35‚Üí
    36‚ÜíFeedback and suggestions welcome‚Äîopen an issue, send a Slack DM, or reach out however works for you. All changes go through PR review.

    40‚ÜíSee [docs/roadmap.md](docs/roadmap.md) for what's planned.

## Development

**Python scripts** use [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/) with inline dependencies (PEP 723). Run scripts with `uv run script.py`. For editor support, run `uv venv && uv pip install <deps>` at the repo root.
